Legal_Issue: Whether the United States Postal Service (USPS) is entitled to claim official marks under the Canadian Trade-marks Act as a public authority
Decision_Outcome: USPS marks were declared not official; Registrar's decisions were set aside
Legal_Rule: Only entities that are public authorities in Canada can claim official marks under subparagraph 9(1)(n)(iii) of the Trade-marks Act
Procedural_Issue: Whether the Registrar erred in granting official mark status to USPS
Grounds_for_Claim: USPS is not a Canadian public authority and therefore ineligible to hold official marks
Outcome_on_Merits: Application allowed; USPS does not qualify as a public authority
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature and structure of USPS as an independent U.S. government establishment; lack of Canadian governmental control
Applicant_Challenge: Canada Post Corporation challenged the Registrarâ€™s decision to grant USPS official marks
Court_Result: In favor of Canada Post Corporation
Defendant_Response: Registrar of Trademarks granted official mark status to USPS based on its status as a public authority
Evidence_Type: Statutory interpretation, organizational structure of USPS
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Registrar's decision
Outcome: USPS cannot claim official marks; decisions set aside
Remedy_Sought: Set aside the Registrar's decisions granting official mark status
Claimant_Status: Canada Post Corporation as applicant for judicial review
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: USPS is not a public authority within the meaning of Canadian law
Applicable_Process: Judicial review under Federal Courts Act
